awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: OpenPath - Improving Student Pathways to Computing Professions via Humanitarian Free and Open Source Software
awd_abstract_narration:
The OpenPath project will improve undergraduate computing education by developing a learning pathway through the computing curriculum that will help address key challenges of computing education via student exposure to and participation in Humanitarian Free and Open Source Software (HFOSS) projects.  HFOSS is open source software that improves the human condition, addressing needs in areas such as health care, disaster management, education, economic development, and accessibility.  Students will be provided with opportunities to positively impact their communities or others, which will engage and motivate traditionally underrepresented minorities and women to pursue careers in computing.  As a result, the OpenPath project will improve student learning and content retention, and will help students to develop professional skills and personal attributes.  

OpenPath will integrate two existing research initiatives: participation in HFOSS, and Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning in Computer Science (CS-POGIL).  In CS-POGIL, students work in small self-managed teams using specifically designed materials to construct their own knowledge.  In this project CS-POGIL will be used to scaffold early learning and help students develop team and process skills.  This early learning will support a transition to more independent learning in HFOSS environments.  Working in an HFOSS project provides students with the skills and professional experience needed to ensure a smooth pathway to the computing professions.  Multiple types of evaluations will enable the research team to track the progress of the project, to determine the legitimacy of the model created and its mapping to the curriculum, to understand the impact of the faculty and student activities, and to identify the student learning that occurs through participation in an HFOSS project.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Preparing students for the complex mix of knowledge and skills needed to become computing professionals is an essential part of computing education. Helping students master fundamental, yet complex, technical topics as well as become problem solvers, communicators and team members is a tremendous challenge. This project, OpenPath, investigated multiple approaches to improving undergraduate computing education through the use of active learning in small groups with an exciting and authentic context.

OpenPath integrated two existing research initiatives: undergraduate participation in Humanitarian Free and Open Source Software (HFOSS), and Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning in Computer Science (CS-POGIL) to work with faculty to integrate HFOSS into existing curricula. Research has shown that HFOSS participation requires significant preparatory learning and development of process skills such as critical thinking, problem solving, and communication. CS-POGIL helps scaffold early learning and develop team and process skills. Through the use of both of these approaches, the OpenPath team completely revised the faculty professional development workshops and researched alternative approaches to HFOSS adoption by faculty into their classes.

OpenPath focused on three areas: (1) Defining the learning progression that enables student participation in HFOSS, (2) Developing learning activities that incorporate POGIL to improve HFOSS participation, and (3) Engaging and expanding the community of computing educators who are enabling student participation in HFOSS as well as the community of HFOSS computing professionals.

Results: Major results of the project can be summarized in four areas:

Professional Development for Faculty - The project team?s prior work adapted a Red Hat, Inc. workshop (POSSE ? Professors? Open Source Software Experience) to prepare faculty to teach HFOSS. Throughout the duration of the OpenPath project, this workshop was completely revised incorporating POGIL techniques and findings from prior work. Over 124 faculty from 99 institutions participated in POSSE under this grant for a total of 176 faculty from 151 institutions across multiple grants.

Course Materials - OpenPath continued development of course materials and reviewed and revised existing materials. Faculty were supported to create and share complete course exemplars demonstrating various ways of integrating HFOSS into the computing curriculum.   The collection contains over 125 learning activities and 13 courses. See http://teachingopensource.org  

Community - OpenPath focused on continued community engagement and expansion. The project supported 11 workshops and small group meetings to explore alternative approaches to HFOSS education and continue materials development.

Alternative Approaches to HFOSS Education - Feedback from faculty who support student involvement in HFOSS projects indicated that faculty need intermediate steps to move from incorporating single learning activities into a course to full participation in an HFOSS project. Two alternative approaches were developed, HFOSS Kits and Faculty-led educational HFOSS projects. Preliminary work was completed in each of these areas and they are the focus of a current NSF-funded project.

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts: OpenPath built upon innovative approaches to improve student learning. HFOSS motivates students and fosters learning for professional practice. POGIL develops process skills and provides initial scaffolding to ease students? progression into the less structured world of HFOSS project involvement.

The approach used in OpenPath is novel, applying well-developed POGIL techniques to HFOSS education, and taking advantage of the emergence of HFOSS to bring an exciting and authentic learning context to computing education. OpenPath provided instructor development to enable instructors and students to engage in an active, small group learning approach to computing. OpenPath connected students with HFOSS professionals, an academic-industry collaboration that many students do not experience. The project?s successes allowed us to continue collaboration with Red Hat, Google, Mozilla and the Software Freedom Conservancy as well as develop new relationships with the Linux Foundation, Wikimedia and OSPO++. The continued and expanding set of collaborations provide a foundation for the long-term sustainability of this effort.

The HFOSS education effort of OpenPath is continuing with a subsequent grant from NSF under the IUSE program.
